text:
It seems reasonable to assume that it should be possible to publish files in a
web server that have the percentage symbol in the file name.  This was possible
in the previous version of Tomcat.

Test scenario:

1) Create directory;
{Catalina}/webapps/ROOT/test/
2) Create text file in the directory called 100%.txt
3) Access the URL;
http://localhost/test/
A valid file listing page is displayed with the correct URL encoded link to the
test file;
/test/100%25.txt
4) Click on the link 
A 400 error code is returned to the browser and the following is logged;
2002-05-09 13:26:19 HttpProcessor[80][4]  Invalid request URI: '/test/100%25.txt'
creator: j.r.maber@leeds.ac.uk

text:
P.S. My application involves users uploading files to the web server through a
servlet and it supports unicode file names on diverse operating systems by
saving the file with a URL encoded name.  The same servlet serves up the files
by decoding URLs approriately and forwarding the request.  Consequently, my
application depends absolutely on the ability to serve up files that have the
percent symbol in the name.
creator: j.r.maber@leeds.ac.uk

text:
There seems to be an intentional block on any request URI that contains an
escaped percent symbol.  This is in the class
org.apache.catalina.connector.http.HttpProcessor in the method normalize(String
path) at line 840.  I assume there is some perceived security risk to allowing
request URIs with an escaped percent symbol.  Can anyone explain why?
creator: j.r.maber@leeds.ac.uk

text:
In 4.0.x, encoding '%' can be used for security exploits, so this will not be 
fixed.
In 4.1.x, the URL decoding process has been cleaned up, so only a less 
intrusive URL normalization is needed.
creator: remm@apache.org
